newsitem.title: USA: Sybase reports profit, names CEO Kertzman chairman.
newsitem.headline: Sybase reports profit, names CEO Kertzman chairman.

text.p: Sybase Inc. on Thursday reported second-quarter earnings that were less than Wall Street expected, on declining sales of its database software products.
The company also said Mitchell Kertzman, its current chief executive, was named chairman of the board, replacing co-founder Mark Hoffman, who left earlier this month to run a new company.
Sybase said it had net income of $4.38 million, or 6 cents a share, compared with a loss of $24.6 million, or 33 cents, in the same quarter a year ago.
Wall Street expected Sybase, based in Emeryville, Calif., to earn 7 cents a share, according to Zacks Investment Research.
Second-quarter revenue declined 4.9 percent to $237.6 million from $249.9 million in the second quarter of 1996.

Sybase writes database software, the computer programmes that store huge amounts of information in corporate computer networks. The company has been struggling to get momentum behind its products going again after marketing missteps two years ago.
The company will release a slate of new products in the second half of the year to attract customers again.
"We're always said we're focused in second-half growth," Kertzman said. "From that point of view, the second quarter reflected our continuing focus on profitibility."

As part of Kertzman's promotion to chairman, John Chen, the former CEO of computer maker Siemens Pyramid Information Systems, was named Sybase president and chief operating officer, taking over Kertzman's day-to-day responsibilities, the company said.
Earlier, Sybase stock rose 75 cents to $15 on Nasdaq.
